comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content:
Another Bain Agency view of the 1914 rooftop crowd, dated 10/9/1914:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/6219794431/in/photostream/]
The non-paying spectators were out there in 1913, as well:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4370902668/]

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: Delightful picture, well worth looking at in the highest resolution for the hundreds of interactions going on across the street from the World Series. Interestingly there are very few women in the picture. lcweb2.loc.gov/master/pnp/ggbain/17500/17511u.tif The story of the 20th Street entrepeneurs who sold space on their roofs and the later "spite fence" controversy when the Shibes built walled bleachers to block their views is told at en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shibe_Park

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: For those interested in historical asides, the buildings two blocks north in the background of the photo, with the watertower marked Lubin Mfg Co, are "Lubinville", a pioneering film studio important in the history of movies. www.youtube.com/watch?v=tb0Nc3Bo308&NR=1
